sections.title: What is going on everybody
bullets: Welcome back to The Common Coder.
My name is Josh and in this video I'm going to be showing you how to use Git with Visual Studio Code.
So let's go ahead and get started.
sections.tldr: What is going on everybody?
cloze: {{c1::Welcome}} back to The Common Coder.
My name is {{c1::Josh}} and in this video I'm going to be showing you how to use Git with Visual Studio Code.
So let's go ahead and get {{c1::started}}

sections.title: All right, so before we get started, we do need to go over a couple of
bullets: So the first thing that you'll need to do is make sure you have VS Code installed.
The next thing you'll need to do is make sure that you have Git installed.
And then optionally, depending on how far you want to go with this video, you'll need to make sure that you have a GitHub account created.
And you'll need to make sure you set up your SSH keys for GitHub so that way you can connect from VS Code or from Git to your GitHub accoun….
sections.tldr: All right, so before we get started, we do need to go over a couple of prerequisites in order to follow along with this video.
cloze: So the first thing that you'll need to do is make sure you have {{c1::VS Code}} installed.
{{c1::The}} next thing you'll need to do is make sure that you have Git installed.
{{c1::And}} then optionally, depending on how far you want to go with this video, you'll need to make sure that you have a GitHub account created.
And you'll need to make sure you set up your SSH keys for GitHub so that way you can connect from {{c1::VS Code}} or from Git to your GitHub accoun….

sections.title: So those parts are optional
bullets: We're mainly going to be covering the Git tooling as it pertains to working with Git inside of VS Code.
But we are going to cover some GitHub-specific features like how to push a branch to GitHub, how to clone things like that.
So I'd recommend you have all of these set up.
And if you need any help with that, I have videos for every single one of these topics, which I'll link down in the description below.
Alright, so with all that out of the way, let's go ahead and start working with Git inside of Visual Studio Code.
sections.tldr: So those parts are optional.
cloze: We're mainly going to be covering the {{c1::Git}} tooling as it pertains to working with Git inside of VS Code.
{{c1::But}} we are going to cover some GitHub-specific features like how to push a branch to GitHub, how to clone things like that.
{{c1::So I}}'d recommend you have all of these set up.
{{c1::And}} if you need any help with that, I have videos for every single one of these topics, which I'll link down in the description below.

sections.title: And what we're going to do is create a folder for our project
bullets: So when working with Visual Studio Code and with Git, your projects are literally just folders.
It's a collection of files and folders.
And Visual Studio Code can open these and you can work with those files inside of those folders.
And then Git basically initializes a repository inside of that folder and keeps track of those changes inside of a special folder called .g….
So it's a little bit out of scope of this course, but just want to let you know what's going on behind the scenes.
sections.tldr: And what we're going to do is create a folder for our project.
cloze: So when working with Visual Studio Code {{c1::And}} with Git, your projects are literally just folders.
It's a collection of files {{c1::And}} folders.
{{c1::And}} Visual Studio Code can open these and you can work with those files inside of those folders.
{{c1::And}} then Git basically initializes a repository inside of that folder and keeps track of those changes inside of a special folder called .g….

sections.title: Now I like to keep all my projects inside of a folder called code
bullets: So I'm going to go ahead and cd into my code directory.
And inside of here, I'm going to go ahead and make a new directory using the makedir command.
And I'm going to call this vscode-git.
And then I'm going to go ahead and cd into that directory.
sections.tldr: Now I like to keep all my projects inside of a folder called code.
cloze: {{c1::So I}}'m going to go ahead and cd into my code directory.
{{c1::And}} inside of here, I'm going to go ahead and make a new directory using the makedir command.
{{c1::And}} I'm going to call this vscode-git.
{{c1::And}} then I'm going to go ahead and cd into that directory.

sections.title: And then I'm going to go ahead and open this folder inside of vscode
bullets: And I can do that by typing code.
Now if you're working on Windows and you've installed Git and vscode, it should have installed that code command for you in the path.
If not, you might have to go back through your installation or manually add the code command into your computer's path.
And if you're on Mac, there's actually a very easy way to do that.
sections.tldr: And then I'm going to go ahead and open this folder inside of vscode.
cloze: {{c1::And}} I can do that by typing code.
Now if you're working on Windows {{c1::And}} you've installed Git and vscode, it should have installed that code command for you in the path.
If not, you might have to go back through your installation or manually add the code command into your computer's {{c1::path}}
{{c1::And}} if you're on Mac, there's actually a very easy way to do that.

sections.title: You can do it from the command palette inside of vscode
bullets: So now that I've opened this folder, you can see that there's no files in it here inside of my file explorer.
And what we want to do is go ahead and initialize this as a new Git repository.
To do that, what we can do is go ahead and go into the source control panel over here on the left.
sections.tldr: You can do it from the command palette inside of vscode.
cloze: So now that I've opened this folder, {{c1::You}} can see that there's no files in it here inside of my file explorer.
{{c1::And}} what we want to do is go ahead and initialize this as a new Git repository.
To do that, what we can do is go ahead {{c1::And}} go into the source control panel over here on the left.

sections.title: And you can see that we don't have a repository initialized
bullets: Otherwise, we would see the status of our repository.
Instead, we get this big blue button that says initialize repository and a link to some documentation for vscode and Git source control.
And you can see if we're also connected to GitHub, we can also publish that repository, basically push the repository up to GitHub.
sections.tldr: And you can see that we don't have a repository initialized.
cloze: {{c1::Otherwise}}, we would see the status of our repository.
Instead, we get this big blue button that says initialize repository {{c1::And}} a link to some documentation for vscode and Git source control.
{{c1::And}} you can see if we're also connected to GitHub, we can also publish that repository, basically push the repository up to GitHub.

sections.title: So we're going to focus on repository creation, working with local fil
bullets: And at the very end, we'll go ahead and talk about how to work with GitHub.
So what I'm going to do is go ahead and click this blue initialize repository button.
And you can see that it has changed the screen here.
And I have an option for my commit message.
I can publish my branch if I'm connected to GitHub.
sections.tldr: So we're going to focus on repository creation, working with local files.

sections.title: And then down here in the bottom left hand corner, you can see that ou
bullets: And we're ready to start working with Git source control inside of vscode.
So clicking that button to initialize the repository is the equivalent of running the git init command inside of the command line.
And what I'm going to actually go ahead and do for the remainder of this video is open up the terminal.
So I can click on the terminal window up here at the top and click new terminal.
I can also press control tilde to toggle my terminal open and closed.
sections.tldr: And then down here in the bottom left hand corner, you can see that our repository has been initialized with a default branch called main.
cloze: {{c1::And}} we're ready to start working with Git source control inside of vscode.
So clicking that button to initialize the repository is the equivalent of running the {{c1::Git}} init command inside of the command line.
{{c1::And}} what I'm going to actually go ahead and do for the remainder of this video is open up the terminal.
So I can click on the terminal window up here at the top {{c1::And}} click new terminal.

It is untracked.
So the repository recognizes there's something there, but as of right now, it's not a tracked file.
So I can't see any history from, you know, versions of that file previously.
It's a brand new file.
I've never committed this file to the repository.

And I can stage all the files at the same time, which puts them inside of this staging area to be committed.

sections.tldr: I can use this little drop down for commit, commit and push or commit and sync if I was connected to get help, which I'm currently am not.

sections.title: And let's just say that I need to work on something else and I'm not q
bullets: I can basically store this file in a temporary location and then retrieve it back when I'm ready to do so.
And this concept is known as a stash inside of git and you usually run the git stash command.
So if I run git stash, that will basically save that working directory in a specific state.
And you can see I don't have that change anymore and my exclamation points are gone.
So we can do that with VS code without having to memorize the git stash command.
sections.tldr: And let's just say that I need to work on something else and I'm not quite ready to commit this change.
cloze: I can basically store this file in a temporary location {{c1::And}} then retrieve it back when I'm ready to do so.
{{c1::And}} this concept is known as a stash inside of git and you usually run the git stash command.
So if I run git stash, that will basically save that working directory in a specific {{c1::state}}
{{c1::And}} you can see I don't have that change anymore and my exclamation points are gone.

takeaways: What is going on everybody?
All right, so before we get started, we do need to go over a couple of prerequisites in order to follow along with this video.
So those parts are optional.
And what we're going to do is create a folder for our project.
Now I like to keep all my projects inside of a folder called code.
And then I'm going to go ahead and open this folder inside of vscode.
You can do it from the command palette inside of vscode.
And you can see that we don't have a repository initialized.
So we're going to focus on repository creation, working with local files.
And then down here in the bottom left hand corner, you can see that our repository has been initialized with a default branch called main.
And that's going to stub out a basic HTML file for me.
now if we go back and look at the source control panel, you can see that there are things happening inside as I work with my files and folders.
So what's happened as of right now is I've created a file and we can see over here on the left hand side, we have this u here, which indicates that there's a n…
Okay, so this is the using that plus is the equivalent of running git add with either an individual file or a collection of files.
And it's going to be dot slash styles.
So you can see now I can use this minus button either up at the top level to unstage all my changes, or I can do each file individually.
So basically the difference between when I started and where I'm at, same thing with style CSS, there's nothing inside of here, which is why there's nothing he…
file looked like at your last commit.
button here.
And I'm going to go ahead and commit these changes to my main branch.
So what I can do is go ahead and click undo last commit.
let's go ahead and make it Azure.
Now let's go ahead and jump back to our file explorer and just make a small change to our index HTML.
So if I go back here and see in the source control panel, again, there's the m for modified.
I can use this little drop down for commit, commit and push or commit and sync if I was connected to get help, which I'm currently am not.
And let's just say that I need to work on something else and I'm not quite ready to commit this change.
